head.title: Song VII.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 223-224.

body.note: Tune. The Pitcher.22 Turnbull's song, including the rhymed half-lines at lines 5-6, match the metre of a song "Friend and Pitcher," published e.g. as Song XXVIII in Calliope, or the Musical Miscellany (London: Elliot and Kay, 1788), pp. 52-53. This version of the song occurs also in John O'Keefe's play The Poor Soldier (also 1783), with the tune there given as "Patrick." An earlier and frequently-reprinted song "The Pitcher," with a refrain (and in some versions first line) beginning "For 'tis not day, 'tis not yet day," occurs in, e.g., The New Merry Companion (London: Wheble, [1780]), pp. 35-36; The Bird: A Choice Collection of Love, Hunting, and Bacchanalian Songs (London: Richardson, 1781), pp. 38-39, and Calliope, pp. 439-440 (words only, referring to the music given earlier at p. 52). A slightly more genteel version of the earlier song is attributed to Burns's friend and patron Robert Riddell of Glenriddell (1755-1794), in William G. Hutchison, Songs of the Vine (London: A.H. Bullen, 1904), pp. 167-168.

lg.l: A Poet ever will be poor,
His wit can never make him richer;
He laughs at fortune, that blind w—re,
And dearly loves his friend and pitcher.
To sing, though we should ne’er be richer,
I’ve all I wish, and all I chuse,
In these two things, a friend and pitcher.
This world is all but toil and care,
And he who has the only share,
Is he who gets a friend and pitcher:
To sing, though we should ne’er be richer,
I’ve all I wish, and all I chuse,
In these two things, a friend and pitcher.
